The colours are vivid, which helps bring the game to life.
His eyes were a vivid green.

senses.definition: able to form pictures of ideas, situations, etc. easily in the mind

examples.x: a wonderfully vivid imagination

senses.definition: the amount of space that an object or a substance fills; the amount of space that a container has

examples.x: How do you measure the volume of a gas?
In the experiment, lighted candles were put under jars of different volumes.
Patients showed an improvement in lung volume.
Wait until the dough doubles in volume before kneading it again.

senses.definition: the amount of something

examples.x: the sheer volume (= large amount) of business
New roads are being built to cope with the increased volume of traffic.
Sales volumes fell 0.2% in June.
The total volume of exports fell by 14.5 per cent.
an attempt to increase the volume of trade
powerful computers that can handle large volumes of data
This work has grown in volume recently.
Due to the volume of mail Mary receives, she may not be able to respond to individual inquiries.

senses.definition: the amount of sound that is produced by a television, radio, etc.

examples.x: to turn the volume up/down
This music is best played at very high volume.
The song has been recorded at a low volume.
He adjusted the volume on his phone.

senses.definition: a book that is part of a series of books

examples.x: an encyclopedia in 20 volumes
The encyclopedia is a huge work, running to 20 volumes.
a companion volume to the one on African wildlife

senses.definition: a book

examples.x: a library of over 50 000 volumes
She published her first book, a slim volume of poetry, at the age of sixteen.

senses.definition: a series of different issues of the same magazine, especially all the issues for one year

examples.x: ‘New Scientist’ volume 142, number 3

senses.definition: a story, play, etc. about a murder in which you do not know who did the murder until the end
a person who shows skill at using words
the job that a person does especially in order to earn money look for

examples.x: He started work as a security guard.
I'm still looking for work.
It is difficult to find work in the present economic climate.
She's planning to return to work once the children start school.
full-time/part-time/unpaid/voluntary work
She had been out of work (= without a job) for a year.
They are in work (= have a job).
What line of work are you in (= what type of work do you do)?
She's been off work (= not going to work) with a bad back since July.

senses.definition: the place where you do your job; the time that you spend there

examples.x: I go to work at 8 o'clock.
I was late for work again.
I have to leave work early today.
Her friends from work came to see her in the hospital.
I get on well with my work colleagues.
a pleasant work environment
The new legislation concerns health and safety at work.
I like to go for a run after work.

senses.definition: the duties that you have and the activities that you do as part of your job

examples.x: Police work is mainly routine.
The accountant described his work to the sales staff.

senses.definition: tasks that need to be done

examples.x: Taking care of a baby is hard work.
Whenever am I going to do all this work?
There is plenty of work to be done in the garden.
Stop talking and get on with your work.
He completed the work shortly before his death.
important work being undertaken by volunteers
Big football matches make a lot of work for the police.

senses.definition: materials needed or used for doing work, especially books, papers, etc.

examples.x: She often brings work (= for example, files and documents) home with her from the office.
His work was spread all over the floor.

senses.definition: the use of physical strength or mental power in order to do or make something

examples.x: She earned her grades through sheer hard work.
We began work on the project last year.
They performed pioneering work on the treatment of cancer.
Work continues on renovating the hotel.
The work of building the bridge took six months.
The art collection was his life's work.
She set them to work painting the fence.

senses.definition: a thing or things that are produced as a result of work

examples.x: She's an artist whose work I really admire.
outstanding work in this area/field
Is this all your own work (= did you do it without help from others)?
The book is a detailed and thorough piece of work covering all aspects of the subject.
He left a substantial body of work—drawings and watercolours as well as oils.

senses.definition: a book, piece of music, painting, etc.

examples.x: the collected/complete works of Tolstoy
works of fiction/literature
Chopin’s piano works
Beethoven composed his greatest works in the latter part of his life.
He recognized the sketch as an early work by Degas.

senses.definition: the result of an action; what is done by somebody

examples.x: The damage is clearly the work of vandals.

senses.definition: activities involving building or repairing something

examples.x: roadworks
They expanded the shipyards and started engineering works.
A contract can ensure that landlords carry out the works for which they are legally responsible.

senses.definition: a place where things are made or industrial processes take place factory

examples.x: an engineering works
a brickworks
Raw materials were carried to the works by barge.

senses.definition: the moving parts of a machine, etc.
everything

examples.x: We went to the chip shop and had the works: fish, chips, gherkins, mushy peas.

senses.definition: the use of force to produce movement
to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil

examples.x: In some countries children don't start learning to read and write until they are six.
Please write in pen on both sides of the paper.
I haven't got anything to write with.
Write your name at the top of the paper.
The teacher wrote the answers on the board.
The ‘b’ had been wrongly written as a ‘d’.

senses.definition: to produce something in written form so that people can read, perform or use it, etc.

examples.x: to write a novel/song/computer program
to write an article/essay
Who was ‘The Grapes of Wrath’ written by?
Which opera did Verdi write first?
He hopes to write a book about his experiences one day.
She had to write a report on the project.
The text is very well written.
The play was originally written for British television.
I wanted to travel and then write about it.
He writes for the ‘New Yorker’ (= works as a writer).
No decision has been made at the time of writing.
She wrote him several poems.

senses.definition: to put information, a message of good wishes, etc. in a letter or an email and send it to somebody

examples.x: Bye! Don't forget to write.
I'm writing to enquire about language courses.
She wrote to him in France.
I wrote a letter to the Publicity Department.
I wrote the Publicity Department a letter.
She wrote that they were all fine.
Write me while you're away.
He wrote me that he would be arriving Monday.
They wrote thanking us for the present.

senses.definition: to state the information or the words mentioned

examples.x: The author writes that this theory has now been disproved.
Ancient historians wrote of a lost continent beneath the ocean.
She wrote of her life in Africa.
‘Of all my books,’ wrote Dickens, ‘I like this the best.’

senses.definition: to put information in the appropriate places on a form

examples.x: to write (out) a cheque
The doctor wrote her a prescription for more antibiotics.
I'll write you out a receipt.

senses.definition: to record data in the memory of a computer

examples.x: An error was reported when he tried to write data to the file for the first time.

senses.definition: to work correctly or in the way mentioned

examples.x: This pen won't write.

senses.definition: a person whose job is writing books, stories, articles, etc.

examples.x: Who's your favourite writer?
a travel/cookery/science fiction writer
a freelance feature writer for ‘Time’ magazine
writers of poetry/fiction
the first Russian writer to win the Nobel Prize for Literature
She left her job to become a full-time writer.

senses.definition: a person who has written a particular thing

examples.x: the writer of this letter
I used to be a prolific letter writer.

senses.definition: a person who forms letters in a particular way when they are writing

examples.x: a messy writer

senses.definition: the activity of writing, in contrast to reading, speaking, etc.

examples.x: Our son’s having problems with his reading and writing (= at school).
a writing case (= containing paper, pens, etc.)
Every morning the children do writing.

senses.definition: the activity of writing books, articles, etc., especially as a job

examples.x: Only later did she discover a talent for writing.
I wanted to try out a new style of writing.
creative writing
feminist/travel writing
He is leaving the band to concentrate on his writing.

senses.definition: books, articles, etc. in general

examples.x: The review is a brilliant piece of writing.

senses.definition: words that have been written or painted on something

examples.x: There was writing all over the desk.

senses.definition: the particular way in which somebody forms letters when they write

examples.x: Who's this from? I don't recognize the writing.

senses.definition: a group of pieces of writing, especially by a particular person or on a particular subject

examples.x: His experiences in India influenced his later writings.
the writings of Hegel
His writings on complex subjects are clear and definitive.

senses.definition: thread that has been spun, used for knitting, making cloth, etc.

examples.x: The sweaters are hand-knitted in cotton, linen or wool yarns.
There's a knot in the yarn.

senses.definition: a long story, especially one that is exaggerated or invented

examples.x: He used to spin yarns (= tell stories) about his time in the army.

senses.definition: used to refer to books, films, television programmes, etc. aimed at teenagers

examples.x: young adult novels/fiction
The movie will appeal to a young adult audience.
